docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: President Bush said that people need to ''gain the skills necessary to fill the jobs of the 21st century.'' Of the dozens of people I know who have been laid off, most have college degrees and all have years of experience in the high-tech industry.

headline.main: After the Debates: Bush and Kerry, Side by Side

docs.abstract: Kathryn Kuchenbrod letter questions Pres Bush's definition of 'jobs of the 21st century'; says she and others she knows have been unable to find jobs with comparable pay and benefits to those they lost
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    President Bush said that people need to ''gain the skills necessary to fill the jobs of the 21st century.'' Of the dozens of people I know who have been laid off, most have college degrees and all have years of experience in the...

docs.lead_paragraph: It would be hard for anyone watching television in this area for any length of time to avoid seeing at least one campaign advertisement about a Congressional race that has turned out to be one of the most competitive in the Northeast. But ever since the incumbent Republican congressman, Jack Quinn, announced this year that he would not seek re-election to a seventh term in the House of Representatives, Democrats have been in a heated battle to take the seat in a district that has a Democratic edge in registration.

headline.main: Retirement Sets Off Battle For Buffalo-Area House Seat

docs.abstract: Nancy A Naples, Republican comptroller of Erie County, NY, and Assemblyman Brian Higgins, Democrat, are in hotly contested race in 27th Congressional District, which takes in parts of Erie and Chautauqua Counties; both national parties are pouring money into district; Democrats believe will they can win; Republicans were given short notice by Rep Jack Quinn that he would not seek re-election; television stations have refused to run several commercials from both sides on ground they they contained misleading statements; photos (M)
docs.snippet: BUFFALO, Oct. 14 - It would be hard for anyone watching television in this area for any length of time to avoid seeing at least one campaign advertisement about a Congressional race that has turned out to be one of the most competitive in the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Coventry Health Care said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a managed health care company, the First Health Group Corporation, for $1.8 billion in cash and stock, to create a national health benefits company capable of providing health insurance and administrative services to a broad array of clients. Coventry said it would pay 0.1791 share and $9.375 in cash for each First Health share, valuing First Health at $18.70 a share, or a 24 percent premium over First Health's closing price on Wednesday of $15.04. Coventry is based in Bethesda, Md. First Health is based in Downers Grove, Ill.

headline.main: COVENTRY AGREES TO PURCHASE FIRST HEALTH GROUP

docs.abstract: Coventry Health Care acquires First Health Group Corp for $1.8 billion in cash and stock (S)
docs.snippet: Coventry Health Care said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a managed health care company, the First Health Group Corporation, for $1.8 billion in cash and stock, to create a national health benefits company capable of providing health insurance...

docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks dropped yesterday as oil prices approached $55 a barrel, renewing concern that fuel costs will reduce spending, and insurance companies became a target for Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general. ''Oil is still on the top of everybody's list,'' said Peter Coolidge, a money manager with the Deltec Asset Management Corporation in New York. ''It adds more uncertainty to the mix.''

headline.main: Insurers Post Steep Losses in Day of Widespread Declines

docs.abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 107.88 points, or 1.1 percent, to 9,894.45; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declines 10.36 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,103.29; Nasdaq composite index falls 17.51 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,903.02; US Treasury prices rise; 10-year note gains 10/32, to price of 101 28/32; yield dips to 4.01 percent from 4.06 percent; graphs; charts (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Eliot Spitzer, the New York state attorney general, yesterday accused the world's largest insurance broker of cheating customers by rigging prices and steering business to insurers in exchange for millions of dollars in kickbacks. The lawsuit brought by Mr. Spitzer against the broker, Marsh Inc., a unit of the Marsh & McLennan Companies, contends that Marsh conducted sham bidding to mislead customers into thinking that they were getting the best price for the coverage they needed. The lawsuit cites several examples of customers -- including Fortune Brands, which sells Titleist golf balls and Jim Beam spirits, and the school district of Greenville, S.C. -- that were misled that way.

headline.main: BROKER ACCUSED OF RIGGING BIDS FOR INSURANCE

docs.abstract: New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer accuses Marsh Inc unit of Marsh & McLennan, world's largest insurance broker, of rigging prices and steering business to insurers in exchange for millions of dollars in kickbacks; files lawsuit charging that Marsh conducted sham bidding to mislead corporate customers; Karen Radke and Jean-Baptist Tateossian of American International Group, one of world's largest insurance companies, plead guilty to rigging bids with Marsh; photos; table of extra commissions to major brokers; Spitzer makes clear he is taking aim at widespread industry practice, saying he has come across wrongdoing in sale of virtually every type of personal insurance; lawsuit names AIG, Hartford, Ace Ltd and Munich Re unit; Marsh chief executive Jeffrey Greenberg and Ace chief Evan Greenberg are sons of Maurice R Greenberg, who built AIG into powerful worldwide insurer; Spitzer began probe on tips about conflict of interest; suit details elaborate farces to fool clients into thinking bidding was competitive, when price had already been determined (M)
docs.snippet: The New York state attorney general accused the world's largest insurance broker of cheating customers by rigging prices in exchange for kickbacks.

docs.lead_paragraph: Much of the presidential debate on Wednesday night turned on the question of whether Americans had more money in their pockets as a result of President Bush's policies. Senator John Kerry offered an array of statistics that in his view showed that people were worse off than they were at the beginning of the Bush presidency.

headline.main: Are Americans Better Off Economically Under Bush? It Depends on How You Look at It

docs.abstract: Comment on question of whether Americans are better off economically under Pres Bush; truth seems to be that, on average, that Americans may have more money at their disposal, but more people are worse off than better off (M)
docs.snippet: The truth seems to be that, on average, Americans may have more money at their disposal. The trick is in the word "average."
